title: 114_hr5910
content: The Act titled "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury to coordinate economic sanctions efforts. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury to coordinate economic sanctions efforts. The Group includes various offices and bureaus such as the Office of International Affairs, Office of Economic Policy, Office of Legislative Affairs, Office of Foreign Assets Control, Office of Intelligence and Analysis, Office of Terrorist Financing, and Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. The Group conducts contingency planning for imposing economic sanctions rapidly under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act or other laws. The contingency planning required for imposing economic sanctions is guided by considerations such as the vulnerability of the foreign country, effectiveness of sanctions, costs to the US economy, and the impact of unilateral vs. multilateral sanctions. The Group will review and identify problems with economic sanctions programs, create a strategy to improve them, and coordinate interagency efforts. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes coordinates US economic sanctions policy with various government departments and agencies, ensuring information sharing. The Group must meet at least once a month, and support staff can be assigned from the Department of the Treasury. The Group must meet at least once a month and can receive support staff from the Department of the Treasury. They are allowed to consult with experts from various sectors and must submit annual reports to Congress. The Group must submit a report to Congress including an overview of contingency planning, problems identified, strategy created, interagency coordination overview, consulted policy experts, and sanctions impact assessment. It may also include a classified index and closed briefings for the House and Senate Intelligence Committees. The Group's report to Congress must include an overview of contingency planning, strategy, interagency coordination, policy expert consultations, and sanctions impact assessment. The assessment should use various research methods and evaluate the impact of sanctions on foreign and US economies. The report to Congress must include an assessment of the impact of sanctions on the economy of the foreign country or entity, the US economy, and any behavioral changes in response to the sanctions. The report will be publicly available on the Department of the Treasury's website. In this section, definitions for "executive agency" and "United States economic sanctions policy" are provided. A new Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group is established to report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury. The establishment of a new Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group is outlined in section 316.
